Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: TTP: Small: STINGAR - Deployment of highly automated, reliable, and fast cybersecurity threat response systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern cybersecurity attacks are often carried out through automated "bots" or agents that systematically attack networks, at scale and in a matter of minutes. This has left organizations scrambling to respond with defenses that must first be validated or enacted by humans, and so take time to mount. Institutions can no longer afford to combat these powerful and rapid digital attacks with our slower and sometimes error-prone analog (human-based) responses. Instead, this project utilizes its own distinctive form of digital protections - which are both automated and scalable - to implement real-time blocks of incoming malicious traffic. The project team seeks to extend a system that has been used successfully for two years at Duke University to other universities, colleges and regional networks with special attention on usability by minority-serving and smaller colleges and universities, where Information Technology (IT) and security personnel may lack the time or expertise to develop similar protections or purchase expensive commercial tools.

The suite of tools that the project has already developed utilizes a series of "sensors" and "actuators," which automatically block certain types of malicious traffic and as a result improve the speed, scale, and reliability of cybersecurity threat responses. This project transitions these tools from Duke to production use at North Carolina Central University (NCCU), with the intention of confirming their usability and ensuring the value derived at Duke is reproducible elsewhere. Then, the project expands coverage to other universities, colleges, and regional networks. The project includes mechanisms to share data among participating universities, thereby "crowdsourcing" awareness of an active attack on any one campus, so that all other campus may proactively enact protections before they fall victim to the same attack.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
New cybersecurity threats are constantly emerging on the internet.  A weakness in many existing cybersecurity protection tools is the long delay (on the order of a day) from first identifying a new cybersecurity threat, and deploying appropriate rules in network security tools to block that specific threat.  Under this project, Duke University has developed and successfully deployed to over 2 dozen partner institutions a new tool dubbed STINGAR (Shared Threat Intelligence for Network Gatekeeping with Automated Response) to address this problem.  Our approach reduces this time to actively protect against new threats from many hours to a few seconds.  To better explain the tool, we will parse the words in its name:

Threat Intelligence - this is the identification of new specific attacks, or threats, that are active on a particular network.  STINGAR can use a variety of sensors to do this, but the current version primarily utilizes honeypots - special computers placed on the network that are intentionally accessible and open to attackers.  Honeypots can simulate any number of "real" internet servers and devices, from a financial system to an Internet-of-Things device.

Network Gatekeeping and Response - STINGAR communicates directly with the routers, switches, network security appliances, and other devices that comprise the networks at large institutions, such as our partner universities and colleges.  As new threats are identified via Threat Intelligence, the threat can be blocked in a matter of seconds from further probing the protected institution's network.  Automation is critical to all of this; all steps from threat identification through deploying a new rule to a network device are fully automated with no human intervention required.

Shared - from the beginning, STINGAR presumed that many internet attackers are targeting higher education as a sector, and not necessarily individual schools.  We expected that if School A, for instance, identifies a new threat and communicates this fact to schools B, C, and D, all the other partners can be protected before seeing the new threat for the first time.  This creates a collective security coverage that is greater than any one school, or partner, could generate for itself.  Two years of operational data confirm that the collective intelligence approach works - though each partner does have some attackers that are apparently focused exclusively on that institution, many of the attackers are seen at multiple schools, and are indeed effectively blocked entirely at partner sites after one school first notices them.

An additional crucial focus of this Transition To Practice grant under the SaTC program was to make STINGAR extremely easy to deploy.  An institution like Duke is blessed with a well-staffed and highly skilled network security office, capable of managing (and indeed developing) novel, complex cybersecurity tools.  Most schools are not so fortunate, especially minority serving institutions and other small colleges and universities, where we find sometimes less than a single Full-Time-Equivalent staff member devoted to cybersecurity.  We partnered from the beginning with North Carolina Central University, a minority-serving institution located in the same city as Duke, to make sure the tools we were developing were indeed easy and intuitive to deploy.  As we grew the STINGAR consortium to over two dozen schools, we have brought in a full range of partners, from high powered research institutions to very small colleges.  Even the smallest schools contribute to the collective defense of the community, and they get the benefit of significant protections from the threats identified at the larger institutions.

STINGAR has now been actively deployed for about 2 years, first at Duke alone and now at more than two dozen schools (see Figure 1).  STINGAR typically blocks 10s of millions of attacks on Duke's network every day, with a peak of up to about 2 billion blocks per day during the time of a particularly nasty internet attack storm.  Though we have developed STINGAR with higher education in mind, it should be equally applicable in other industry sectors.  Duke is actively exploring opportunities to commercialize or otherwise sustain STINGAR for the long term.


Last Modified: 11/30/2020
Modified by: John A Board

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: New cybersecurity threats are constantly emerging on the internet. A weakness in many existing cybersecurity protection tools is the long delay (on the order of a day) from first identifying a new cybersecurity threat, and deploying appropriate rules in network security tools to block that specific threat. Under this project, Duke University has developed and successfully deployed to over 2 dozen partner institutions a new tool dubbed STINGAR (Shared Threat Intelligence for Network Gatekeeping with Automated Response) to address this problem. Our approach reduces this time to actively protect against new threats from many hours to a few seconds. To better explain the tool, we will parse the words in its name: Threat Intelligence - this is the identification of new specific attacks, or threats, that are active on a particular network. STINGAR can use a variety of sensors to do this, but the current version primarily utilizes honeypots - special computers placed on the network that are intentionally accessible and open to attackers. Honeypots can simulate any number of "real" internet servers and devices, from a financial system to an Internet-of-Things device. Network Gatekeeping and Response - STINGAR communicates directly with the routers, switches, network security appliances, and other devices that comprise the networks at large institutions, such as our partner universities and colleges. As new threats are identified via Threat Intelligence, the threat can be blocked in a matter of seconds from further probing the protected institution's network. Automation is critical to all of this; all steps from threat identification through deploying a new rule to a network device are fully automated with no human intervention required. Shared - from the beginning, STINGAR presumed that many internet attackers are targeting higher education as a sector, and not necessarily individual schools. We expected that if School A, for instance, identifies a new threat and communicates this fact to schools B, C, and D, all the other partners can be protected before seeing the new threat for the first time. This creates a collective security coverage that is greater than any one school, or partner, could generate for itself. Two years of operational data confirm that the collective intelligence approach works - though each partner does have some attackers that are apparently focused exclusively on that institution, many of the attackers are seen at multiple schools, and are indeed effectively blocked entirely at partner sites after one school first notices them. An additional crucial focus of this Transition To Practice grant under the SaTC program was to make STINGAR extremely easy to deploy. An institution like Duke is blessed with a well-staffed and highly skilled network security office, capable of managing (and indeed developing) novel, complex cybersecurity tools. Most schools are not so fortunate, especially minority serving institutions and other small colleges and universities, where we find sometimes less than a single Full-Time-Equivalent staff member devoted to cybersecurity. We partnered from the beginning with North Carolina Central University, a minority-serving institution located in the same city as Duke, to make sure the tools we were developing were indeed easy and intuitive to deploy. As we grew the STINGAR consortium to over two dozen schools, we have brought in a full range of partners, from high powered research institutions to very small colleges. Even the smallest schools contribute to the collective defense of the community, and they get the benefit of significant protections from the threats identified at the larger institutions. STINGAR has now been actively deployed for about 2 years, first at Duke alone and now at more than two dozen schools (see Figure 1). STINGAR typically blocks 10s of millions of attacks on Duke's network every day, with a peak of up to about 2 billion blocks per day during the time of a particularly nasty internet attack storm. Though we have developed STINGAR with higher education in mind, it should be equally applicable in other industry sectors. Duke is actively exploring opportunities to commercialize or otherwise sustain STINGAR for the long term. Last Modified: 11/30/2020 Submitted by: John A Board
